No, Mr Chairperson, because if it was - if I had to tell them they also would have been involved in this operation.
Then finally on the same aspect - whose responsibility was it to report to your senior officers on the success of the mission?
Chairperson, I believe it was Jan de Wet's instruction because he was on his way back to the base where they were stationed.

No, not what you believe, what you know?
If you don't know then you don't know, not what you believe.

Whose responsibility was it to inform your superior officers that you had been successful in Germiston?
You after all had the activator, you pressed those wires together?

Yes,Mr Chairperson, I put the wires together against the battery's terminals but it was De Wet's task to go and report back to Nicolas Barnard and that was how the instruction was given, that he must go back and give a report to him.
At the stage when you left for Koesterfontein, where was General Prinsloo and Brigadier van der Merwe?
When did General Prinsloo or rather Brigadier van der Merwe, when did he give you the instruction to accompany people to Koesterfontein?
Chairperson, that was in Ventersdorp at the Trimpark.
Was that the previous day?  The Friday already or when was this?
No, Chairperson, that was when we got together at the Trimpark and when the Ystergarde gathered together when they were called up the first time.

Because you sat with two instructions when you went to Koesterfontein and one was that of Brigadier van der Merwe, that is accompany people to Koesterfontein, did he say you have to return then, is that how you understood it?

When Brigadier van der Merwe told you to accompany people to Koesterfontein, did you understand that you must go and do something at Koesterfontein or did you understand you must then return to your base?
At that stage I believed I must return to Ventersdorp.
And when you went to Koesterfontein, you actually went there to go and help build bombs?

Chairperson, as I've said before, it was the Sunday the 24th and then Abraham Myburgh and Nicolas Barnard arrived at the Garde House and they gave me the instruction to accompany them to Koesterfontein.
But to make bombs?  Did they tell you then it's to make bombs at the Garde House?
Did you not know where Brigadier van der Merwe was at that stage?
I was under the impression that he was at the game farm and I believed that's where he went the day they left Ventersdorp.

Wasn't there anyone else that you could talk about with regards to these two instructions because now you have two instructions - one is go to Koesterfontein and then you returned and the other instruction is go to Koesterfontein and build bombs.
Cliff Barnard told me that Brigadier Leon van der Merwe said that I must go to Koesterfontein.
And when you returned where was General Prinsloo and Leon van der Merwe then, after the bomb now?
I do not know Chairperson, I believe they were still at the game farm.
Mr Vlok, the making of a bomb, how late in the day did this happen?
Chairperson, I do not know what time on Sunday the 24th they started making the bomb but I know I was there just after dark and the bomb was at an advanced stage.
And how late in the day was the sand thrown over the bomb in the trailer?
Yes, the next morning, the 25th, very early.
Yes, Chairperson, the sun was already up.
Is this April month, the month of April and then de Wet arrived?
Now did it take you the whole night to make the bomb?
Who was in charge of you guys?

He gave me the order that I must go with Jan de Wet to Germiston but Koekemoer was in charge of the actual making of the bomb, he built the bomb.  He gave the people instructions how to build a bomb and to place the bomb on the trailer.
Yes, we understand that, but I'm not talking about in whose charge you were, who was the Commander, let me put it that way of Koesterfontein that evening?
Several occasions, you in your evidence said that you acted in the interests of the AWB - which interests is this?

Chairperson, the interests of the AWB was at that stage to stop the elections and to enforce a Volkstaat and if they would not give us a Volkstaat, we thought we'll enforce it because at that stage we thought, we were under the impression that the ANC government - the future ANC government would not give us an election once they come to power.

Just before you brought about this bomb in Germiston or you accomplished the exploding of a bomb, did you try and find out from head office if the Volkstaat was handed over to you, just before you detonated the bomb?
No Chairperson, I feel then we would have been stopped by our commanding structure as the messages were conveyed down from the top.
But you knew you going to plant a bomb and you're going to detonate the bomb and people are going to be killed, is that not true?
Did you think before we take these people's lives just for final sake let's just contact head office and just find out if maybe we did succeed in obtaining this Volkstaat?
And the question is?  No we did not contact them.
No Chairperson because I believed that I was there to perform my task and automatically it would have come from the top if we had to stop.  It was my task and I had to perform it.
Please tell me, when you received the instruction - I'm not quite sure what was your exact instruction but as I understand your evidence at least you had to take these people to a farm.
What would have happened if you said "I don't want to"?

At that stage I do not know but then I believed that there was no turning around, that's what Nicolas Barnard also told us.  My purpose was there that I wanted to achieve my purpose and we also had an oath in the Garde which said that if you turn around or you turn away from them you would be shot and at that stage we were in a war situation and there was no turning back.
Is that the reason - let me put it this way - is that what you were scared of, that you might be killed, you might be shot dead?

Did you fear that you might get shot?
In other words, the possibility that if you turned around that you might be shot - did you believe in that possibility?

I'm asking this question because several times during your evidence you make mention of the fact that you acted according to instructions and that these instructions, you were following these instructions.  Now these instructions, did you obey them under force, under coercion?
No, Chairperson, not at all, I was there because I believed in the principles of the AWB and that was why I was willing to even give my life for the cause.

Because Mr Kriel and Brasher asked you did you not think about the lives of the people who died and both times you answered "I acted according to my instructions" that's why I'm asking you - did you feel that act under coercion?
No Chairperson, I acted in accordance with what I believed which was the Volkstaat.
Did you not think about the lives that you were going to take?
No Chairperson because at that stage I was desperate to share my Volkstaat with my people and to stop the elections so that our demands would be met.
Now you're saying that the policy as you understood it and you believed in this policy that each race in this country must look after itself.  Did I understand you correctly?
Now how many races were you thinking about?
Well Chairperson, at that stage I saw it as all the different nations who lived together in this country.  Each one had the right to self-determination.
But how many races or nations were you taking into consideration then?
If you say take into consideration, what do you mean?
In other words, how many did you think about?  That in this country how many of them should govern themselves in this country?

At that stage I thought about the ANC government and the same way they wanted South Africa, we as Afrikaner Boerevolk wanted our own bit of ground, Chairperson, our own bit of land because we knew that the ANC would win the elections, it was quite evident from the amounts of people representing the ANC and looking at the amounts representing the Afrikaner Volk, you can't even compare it and it's impossible to win an election.

I'm not talking about elections, Mr Vlok, I not talking about states of nation, I'm simply asking you - if it was the policy as you understood it - the policy of the AWB that is - that each nation must look after itself, how many nations were you talking about within this country?
Each one that's being represented, Chairperson, Tswanas, Xhosas, Vendas, Portuguese people, each one, Greeks, the English and the Afrikaners.
I wonder how that flag would have looked.  In any case, what did you did in the furthering of this policy that each race would look after itself - or nation?
Please repeat, I do not understand.

What did you or the AWB do to further this policy, the policy which says each person must look after itself, each nation must look after itself.  For example you named Tswanas or Greeks - what would you do with regard to the Greeks?  How would you have helped them?

No, then I misunderstood you Chairperson, I will take you back to the answer earlier.  From what I understood from your question was that you were asking me who are all represented in this country and that's how I saw it.
Well, it get's to that, what I really want to know is, how many nations did you conceive who would be looking after themselves?
I do not understand what you mean, what did you conceive, I cannot remember the question before that?

If there were so many nations in this country and each nation agrees that they want self-determination, then it wouldn't have been necessary to obtain an Afrikaner Volkstaat for the Afrikaner Boere, because then everybody would have lived in South Africa without problems, is that not true?

No, Chairperson, I saw that we as Afrikaner volk also had the right, as all the other nations, we had the right to live in our own land.  The fact of the matter is, the Afrikaner Boerevolk did not have a piece of land of it's own where he can be governed by his own people where they cannot be governed by their own Boerevolk leaders and that's why I identified to that, that's why I fought for them.

Let's say it was a possibility and the Greeks and the Tswanas and everyone, they all agree - but South Africa was not divided in areas like that.  Now in terms of the policy of the AWB, what did you do in order to accomplish that on behalf of the Greek people?
I did not represent the Greek people.

Yes, but how would the AWB accomplish this, all these small little states, surely it couldn't only be for the Afrikaner Boerevolk according to your policy?  According to your policy you couldn't only have it for the Afrikaners, according to your policy each nation must have his own piece of land.  How did you try and bring about the policy of the AWB with regards to all the nations?
Unfortunately, I still don't understand you.
The Volkstaat, if I understand you correctly, the Volkstaat idea was for the Afrikaner where they would be governed by the Afrikaners.
No, outside of the borders of the Volkstaat, the rest of the nations would have been able to govern themselves and they would have had their say to the government.
No, I don't understand you because earlier in your evidence you spoke about the purity of nations, do you remember that?
Now the purity of nations, I understand is Greeks, Tswanas, is that not true.
Yes, each is a nation on it's own.
And it's the policy of the AWB?
Each one has a culture of it's own, a religion and principles according to which they live and that's what the AWB is trying to achieve.
But up until 1994, up until that time, what did the AWB do in terms of the Greek states in South Africa, what did they try and do to try and accomplish that?
Nothing that I know of Chairperson, nothing.
So it was only about the Afrikaner Boerevolk, the Volkstaat?
Yes, that would have been for the Afrikaner.
One last question, you testified that you wanted to speak the truth and to reconcile, is that correct?  What reconciliation are you talking about, what do you understand with that?

Chairperson, reconciliation means as I understand it that you come in front of this Committee and you tell them that you were fighting a struggle at that time and you come and tell this to the world and to the Committee here and that order you can take a decision whether there will be amnesty or not and to
express my sympathy and condolences to the families outside who died because of the objectives we wanted to achieve and to tell them that we are sorry.
And do you want to reconcile yourself with them?
Chairperson as I have said, I give my condolences and if I get amnesty I would like to go out, back to my house where I live in the Cape and I want to be able to continue with my life in peace.
I do not understand you, do you want to reconcile with the people who suffered in one or other way because of that bomb?
Do you want to open your heart towards them?
Yes, Chairperson, that's why I came here and sat here and told you about the things that I did.
Did you make any effort to speak to them?

Chairperson, I was on the run for two years and almost three months yesterday, that's why I'm sitting here so I'd like to tell the victims' parents of these things so that they also know what happened.
But did you actually go to them and try and talk to them and tell them how sorry you are and that you've changed?
I thought that would be the chance I'll be granted now, when I'm sitting in front of you.
Are you willing to make such an effort after the hearing to go and talk to them yourself?
You applicants, have you discussed this amongst yourselves?
No, Chairperson, because we want to finish the case first and then the families of the victims, if they approve of it and they accept our apologies.
How are you going to find out about this?
How are you going to find out?
We'll discuss it amongst ourselves as soon as we get together again and from there we can act.
What would be the position if we refuse to give you amnesty, would you still try to go and reconcile yourself with these people?
